title: 108_hr2630
content: The Act may be cited as the "Commercial Alien Smuggling Elimination Act of 2003" or the "CASE Act of 2003." It introduces a new class of nonimmigrant aliens. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include a new clause for nonimmigrant aliens who possess critical information on alien smuggling organizations and are essential to criminal investigations. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include provisions for nonimmigrant aliens deemed essential for criminal investigations related to alien smuggling organizations. The number of such aliens admitted in a fiscal year is limited. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to limit the number of nonimmigrant aliens admitted under section 101(a)(15)(S)(iii) to 400 per fiscal year. Officials are authorized to take necessary actions to protect the identity of such nonimmigrants and their family members. SEC. 3. Adjustment of status of nonimmigrant to that of person admitted for permanent residence. Section 245(j) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to allow the Secretary of Homeland Security to adjust the status of a nonimmigrant admitted under a specific section to that of an alien lawfully admitted for permanent residence under certain conditions related to alien smuggling investigations. The Secretary of Homeland Security may adjust the status of certain aliens to that of lawful permanent residents under specific conditions, including protection of identity if necessary. SEC. 4. BRINGING IN AND HARBORING CERTAIN ALIENS. Criminal penalties under the Immigration and Nationality Act are increased by up to 10 years for individuals involved in bringing aliens into the US in violation of the law, under certain conditions. A rewards program is established to combat commercial alien smuggling. A rewards program is established by the Department of Homeland Security to combat commercial alien smuggling involving groups of 10 or more aliens in dangerous conditions. The program is administered by the Secretary of Homeland Security and allows for the payment of rewards to individuals providing information leading to the prevention of such smuggling activities. The Secretary of Homeland Security may pay rewards to individuals providing information leading to the arrest or conviction of those involved in commercial alien smuggling of groups of 10 or more aliens in dangerous conditions. The Secretary of Homeland Security may pay rewards for information leading to the arrest or conviction of individuals involved in commercial alien smuggling, including those aiding or abetting the act, preventing or dismantling smuggling operations, and identifying key leaders in dangerous smuggling operations. Authorization of appropriations is provided for this purpose. The Secretary of Homeland Security may pay rewards for information leading to the arrest or conviction of individuals involved in commercial alien smuggling. Authorization of appropriations is provided for this purpose. An officer or employee of any government who furnishes information while in official duties is ineligible for a reward. Protection measures can be taken to safeguard the identity of individuals providing information. The Secretary of Homeland Security may pay rewards for information leading to the arrest or conviction of individuals involved in commercial alien smuggling. Rewards are limited to $100,000 unless authorized by the Secretary for combating large-scale smuggling operations endangering lives. Protection measures can be taken to safeguard the identity of informants and their family members. The Secretary of Homeland Security may pay rewards exceeding $50,000 for combating commercial alien smuggling operations endangering lives or posing health risks. Rewards exceeding $50,000 require personal approval by the Secretary and certification for payment. Additionally, an outreach program will be developed in consultation with the Attorney General and the Secretary of State. The Secretary of Homeland Security will develop an outreach program in consultation with the Attorney General and the Secretary of State to educate the public about penalties for harboring aliens and incentives for assisting in combating commercial smuggling operations.
